source_id: STP1529-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_16th Volume_007_chunk1
evidence_span: Zirconium's corrosion resistance is exceptional in a broad range of aggressively corrosive environments.

conditions.medium: broad range of aggressively corrosive environments

source_id: STP1529-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_16th Volume_007_chunk1
evidence_span: Zirconium clad has become a broadly accepted material of construction for a significant range of chemical process equipment.

source_id: STP1529-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_16th Volume_007_chunk1
evidence_span: Zirconium clad and related design, manufacture, and fabrication processes have been shown to be highly reliable and to reduce both capital and operating cost.

source_id: STP1529-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_16th Volume_007_chunk1
evidence_span: It exhibits excellent resistance to corrosive attack in most organic and inorganic acids, salt solutions, and strong alkalis.

conditions.medium: most organic and inorganic acids, salt solutions, and strong alkalis

source_id: STP1529-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_16th Volume_007_chunk1
evidence_span: Zirconium's ability to withstand alternating acidic and basic environments is unusual.

source_id: STP1529-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_16th Volume_007_chunk1
evidence_span: Zirconium alloy R60702 (ASTM B551 Alloy 702) [4], which is essentially chemically pure zirconium, is the most commonly used grade (Table 1).

source_id: STP1529-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_16th Volume_007_chunk1
evidence_span: allowable design strength for R60702 drops off more quickly with increasing temperature than that of stainless steels and nickel alloys (Fig. 1).

source_id: STP1529-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_16th Volume_007_chunk1
evidence_span: Clad of $3 \mathrm { m m }$ thick $\mathrm { Z r }$ bonded to steel (ASTM A516-70) [6] is commonly used for pressure vessels.

source_id: STP1529-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_16th Volume_007_chunk1
evidence_span: A thicker cladding layer, $\mathrm { 8 ~ m m }$ , is commonly used for heat exchanger tubesheets.

source_id: STP1529-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_16th Volume_007_chunk1
evidence_span: clad typically offers cost benefits over solid R60702 construction when the required wall thickness of R60702 exceeds $1 5 ~ \mathrm { m m }$ .
property_name: wall thickness threshold for cost benefit

source_id: STP1529-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_16th Volume_007_chunk2
evidence_span: Typical bond shear strength of zirconium clad manufactured Dynamic Materials Corporation (DMC) is around $2 0 0 \ \mathrm { M P a }$

source_id: STP1529-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_16th Volume_007_chunk2
evidence_span: Optical microscopy shows no evidence of heating. No significant melt layers can be observed.

source_id: STP1529-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_16th Volume_007_chunk2
evidence_span: There is significant cold work in the waves and no recrystallization is evident.

source_id: STP1529-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_16th Volume_007_chunk2
evidence_span: Scanning electron microscopy studies show no evidence of diffusion.

source_id: STP1529-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_16th Volume_007_chunk3
evidence_span: A review of manufacturing records indicates that three zirconium clad pressure vessels were put into service in the 1980s, 12 in the 1990s, and over 30 in the 20002009 time period.

source_id: STP1529-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_16th Volume_007_chunk3
evidence_span: A review of manufacturing records indicates that three zirconium clad pressure vessels were put into service in the 1980s, 12 in the 1990s, and over 30 in the 20002009 time period.

source_id: STP1529-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_16th Volume_007_chunk3
evidence_span: Over this period, hundreds of zirconium heat exchangers with clad tubesheets were put into service.

source_id: STP1529-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_16th Volume_007_chunk3
evidence_span: Zirconium is an exceptional material for containment of corrosive media in CPI processes. The corrosion resistance of zirconium is exceptional in a broad range of aggressively corrosive environments.

source_id: STP1529-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_16th Volume_007_chunk9
evidence_span: Etoh et al. [35] conducted postirradiation corrosion tests on as-irradiated and on irradiated and annealed nodule-susceptible Zircaloy-2. They found that nodular-susceptible Zircaloy did not form nodules when corrosion tested after irradiation. However, when postirradiation annealing was performed to precipitate the solutes into SPPs prior to corrosion testing, nodules formed in subsequent corrosion testing

evidence_span: Fe and Ni in the oxide could shift the surface potential, thereby reducing nodule susceptibility.

evidence_span: increasing of Fe content does not considerably affect the IIG (Fig. 8). Thus, the relation of the irradiation growth to the iron content of the Zr-1Nb type alloys was revealed. It has been shown that a higher Fe content of the alloy lowers down IIG, but mainly at the expense of its increasing in solid solution. At the Fe content above the solubility limit, the effect becomes weaker.
